title: Thomas Alva Edison
brief_description: After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Thomas Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats.

constellations_primary.name: Thomas Edison
constellations_primary.description: Thomas Edison helped establish cinema as an art-form and mass entertainment. Many of his early films were short and showed everyday activities like riding a bicycle.

description: Thomas Edison daydreamed at school. Though his teachers were unimpressed, the American inventor later imagined numerous innovative devices and processes. He improved the telegraph system and created the first commercially practical light bulb, as well as the phonograph sound recorder. After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats. One film was Fred Ott’s Sneeze (1894), which, like many of the films, Dickson produced with another Edison invention, the Kinetograph, the first motion-picture camera. These inventions contributed to filmmaking as we know it – and prove it pays to daydream.
